Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: Organization of Tropical Convection in Numerical Model Simulations: Self-Aggregation and Tropical Cyclogenesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical clouds and thunderstorms, known as tropical convection, are often organized into clusters containing many individual cells. These clusters play a significant role in impacting precipitation distribution and local temperatures, as well as large-scale wind and moisture patterns. Prior numerical modeling studies have shown that convection has the ability to self-organize through interactions between the broader environment and the convection, a process known as "self-aggregation". In this work, the researcher will apply the concept of self-aggregation to the formation of tropical cyclones. The project will be modeling-based, with simulations of tropical convection in both idealized and realistic model setups. A successful completion of the work would lead to improved understanding of the formation of tropical cyclones and the potential for better forecasts. The work will also benefit climate models by providing a more accurate representation of tropical convection. The researcher plans to contribute to increasing public understanding of science by participating in a variety of public outreach efforts.

The main objective of the project is to determine the role of convective self-aggregation in tropical cyclogenesis. Three main tasks will be addressed. The researcher will first conduct a feedback analysis of spontaneous tropical cyclogenesis. This involves simulations using the System for Atmospheric Modeling (SAM). Rather than impose an external forcing on the modeled convection, the researcher will let the circulation be allowed to develop spontaneously. A feedback analysis will allow the researcher to directly compare the spontaneous genesis of a tropical cyclone to the development of a non-rotating self-aggregated cluster. The second step of the research plan will be to compare the genesis processes in the cloud-resolving simulations above to those processes in climate models. The final step of the research plan will be to study the mechanisms of convective organization in a more realistic cloud resolving simulation by forcing a wave disturbance through the model domain and by including background shear.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My research is about tropical convection and hurricanes. I studied how tropical clouds clump together into clusters, what impact this clustering has on the broader climate, and how this clustering might affect and respond to climate change. The particular type of clustering I explored is known as "self-aggregation", which is the tendency of tropical clouds to spontaneously clump together, soley due to interactions between the clouds and the surrounding environment. It occurs in numerical model simulations of an imaginary patch of the tropical atmosphere, in which the model starts off with the same temperature and moisture everywhere over a uniform, fixed temperature ocean surface. This transition from random to clustered clouds has a big impact on the clouds, humidity, and circulation. One important result from my research was an understanding of how this clustering works in different sorts of model geometries, such as those that allow for a range of interactions between individual clouds and large-scale circulation (which is more realistic than earlier work). Another key outcome is that, because these simulations both resolve clouds explicitly and contain large-scale circulations, they are a valuable tool to explore changes in clouds, precipitation, and circulation with warming, and to explore tropical cloud feedbacks and climate sensitivity. There remains uncertainty about these issues in the climate literature, so my work is valuable since it provides another tool to understand these important changes. 

I also studied how the mechanisms governing how clouds cluster affect the formation of one very special type of tropical cloud system - hurricanes. Hurricanes have the potential to cause a great deal of devastation and destruction, so a better understanding of how they form is very important for society. In particular, there is currently no accepted theory for what controls the number of hurricanes in a given climate. This is one of the largest unanswered questions in tropical meteorology, and my results on the fundamental physics of hurricane formation and intensification will contribute to solving this problem. The attached figure shows a hurricane that was spontaneously generated in a cloud resolving model simulation. I found that the hurricane formed by the same self-aggregation mechanisms ("radiative-convective feedbacks") that led to the cloud clustering in my other, non-rotating, simulations.  In particular, I found that feedbacks involving the interaction of clouds and radiative cooling were important to the formation of a weak vortex, which subsequently spun up into a hurricane. These results have the potential to change the way we think about hurricane formation. I also analyzed hurricanes simulated by high resolution climate models, which parameterize clouds and convection, and compared their genesis processes to those in the cloud resovling simulations, including the role of cloud-radiative feedbacks. To acheive this, I introduced a new analysis method which can be used as a process-oriented diagnostic of the simulation of hurricanes in climate models. This is useful because, while climate models have improved such that they can simulate the climatology of hurricanes with some fidelity, biases remain. Therefore it is important to identify model characteristics that are responsible for a good simulation of hurricanes, so that the simulation and prediction of hurricane activity in climate models can be improved. 

In addition to the impact of my scientific results to the societally-relevant problems of hurricane formation, simulation of hurricanes in climate models, and understanding of tropical clouds and precipitation, I have also had the opportunity to engage in public outreach about atmospheric and climate science. This outreach has taken numerous forms, ranging from writing blog posts for the general public about hurricanes, to speaking with middle and high school and undergraduate students about career opportunities in atmospheric science, to sharing my enthusiasm about weather and climate with visitors of all ages by performing rotating fluid tank demonstrations at our open house. 

In summary, my research has enriched our fundamental understanding of hurricane formation by revealing the role of radiative-convective feedbacks. It also has yielded insights on mechanisms of convective organization, more generally, with potential applications ranging from improving climate model convective parameterizations to aiding theoretical understanding of observed tropical convective variability. This project has also led to a novel approach to understanding changes in clouds, circulation, and precipitation with warming, and the development of a new diagnostic to evaluation the simulation of hurricanes in climate models.
